coredata.dc:description: High performance and cost-effective electrocatalysts are crucial to the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in water splitting. Herein, we use density functional theory (DFT) calculation to systematically explore the catalytic activities of single-metallic organic frameworks (s-MOFs, such as Fe36C108O156), dual-metallic organic frameworks (d-MOFs, such as Fe26Co10C108O156, Fe30Ni6C108O156), and tri-metallic organic frameworks (t-MOFs, such as Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156) for electrocatalytic OER. The DFT calculation and experimental results suggest that the OER performance could be promoted with reduced activation energy barrier and accelerated kinetics by introducing Co and Ni into the unit cell of Material of Institute Lavioisier (MIL). The optimized t-MOFs exhibited an ultra-low overpotential of only 200 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a small Tafel slope of 34 mV dec−1. This work proposes that the t-MOFs induced multi-metallic active sites and synergetic effect are promising strategies in designing highly efficient and robust OER electrocatalysts.

head.ce:title: Theoretical and experimental exploration of tri-metallic organic frameworks (t-MOFs) for efficient electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: High performance and cost-effective electrocatalysts are crucial to the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in water splitting. Herein, we use density functional theory (DFT) calculation to systematically explore the catalytic activities of single-metallic organic frameworks (s-MOFs, such as Fe36C108O156), dual-metallic organic frameworks (d-MOFs, such as Fe26Co10C108O156, Fe30Ni6C108O156), and tri-metallic organic frameworks (t-MOFs, such as Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156) for electrocatalytic OER. The DFT calculation and experimental results suggest that the OER performance could be promoted with reduced activation energy barrier and accelerated kinetics by introducing Co and Ni into the unit cell of Material of Institute Lavioisier (MIL). The optimized t-MOFs exhibited an ultra-low overpotential of only 200 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a small Tafel slope of 34 mV dec−1. This work proposes that the t-MOFs induced multi-metallic active sites and synergetic effect are promising strategies in designing highly efficient and robust OER electrocatalysts.

Reduced energy barriers for the rate-determining step and creation of active reaction sites for oxygen evaluation reaction (OER) facilitate the as-prepared Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP trimetallic organic frameworks (t-MOFs) electrode to deliver remarkable electrocatalytic OER performance.
ga1

ce:section.ce:para: The development of electrocatalysis-based energy conversion and storage technologies, such as electrocatalytic water splitting, metal-air batteries, and regenerative fuel cells, is of great importance to produce clean and renewable energy [1]. Electrochemical oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is an essential half-reaction in these energy conversion and storage systems [2,3]. However, OER involves a multistep proton-coupling and electron-transfer process, and its efficiency is severely hindered by sluggish kinetics [4]. Although the excellent OER electrocatalytic activity can be achieved on noble-metal-based iridium and ruthenium oxides (e.g., IrO2 and RuO2), the high cost and scarcity of noble metals are the limiting factors for their large-scale applications [5,6]. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop efficient electrocatalysts with low-cost and earth-abundant resources to achieve a low overpotential for OER.

Through years of efforts, a wide variety of materials, including transition metals oxides [7], hydroxides [8], phosphides [9], and sulfides [10] and nitrides [11], have been explored and applied as the electrocatalysts for OER. Apart from these transition metal compounds, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), constructed by the metal ions and organic linkers with periodical arrangements, are also promising candidates and have attracted considerable attention [12]. Due to their well-defined coordination environments, structural flexibility, and component tunability, MOFs exhibit unique physical and chemical features. They have been widely investigated as catalysts or precursors for the fabrication of non-precious catalysts for electrocatalysis [13–15]. However, the pristine MOFs suffer from low electrical conductivity and inferior stability in the harsh environment, making it hard to be utilized in OER directly. On the other hand, when they serve as the precursor to produce carbon-based composites through high-temperature pyrolysis, the ordered structure and well-defined coordination environments will be destroyed, leading to the decrease of active sites [12,16,17]. Therefore, advanced strategies are much needed for the rational design of MOFs and enhancing their intrinsic conductivity and activity for direct use in OER.

Generally, the electrocatalytic performance is highly dependent on the number of active sites, the intrinsic conductivity, and the reaction energy barrier [18,19]. Attributed to the tunable composition, the coordination environment of MOFs can be precisely tailored at the atomic level by using different metal ions and organic linkers. As the metal center has been regarded as the potential active site and affects the properties of MOFs, constructing secondary or ternary alloy-like MOFs with multi-metallic building units can be an effective method to enhance the intrinsic activity of pristine MOFs without changing their structure [20–22]. For example, based on the theoretical calculations, Bu’s group demonstrated the bimetallic MOFs display improved OER activity compared with single-metal MOFs [23]. Likewise, Gu et al. confirmed that the combination of bimetal atoms optimized the reaction energy barrier significantly to offer better OER activity [24]. It is expected that the incorporation of multi-metallic elements can achieve the optimized electronic structure for enhanced electron transfer and favorable intermediate binding energies toward OER.

However, the electrocatalytic mechanisms of t-MOFs, d-MOFs, and s-MOFs need to be investigated both theoretically and experimentally. Herein, we adopted MIL-88A, a kind of MOFs with the unsaturated Fe coordination center, as the study object. The composition engineering was conducted to boost its OER activity. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggest that the reduced energy barriers for the rate-determining step are achieved by the substitution of Fe with Co and Ni atoms in the unit cell of MIL-88A. Inspired by the results of DFT calculation, the tri-metallic Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL has been successfully prepared and in-situ grown on the carbon fiber paper (CFP) as the integrated electrode for OER. Benefiting from the synergistic effect of tri-metallic components, the optimized Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP electrode presented significantly enhanced OER activity in comparison to its single-metallic (Fe3-MIL/CFP) and dual-metallic counterparts (Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL/CFP and Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL/CFP).

All chemicals and solvents were used directly without further purification. Iron (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Fe(NO3)3 ·9H2O), Nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2 ·6H2O, 98%), Cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2 ·6H2O, 99%), Fumaric acid (99%) and potassium hydroxide (KOH) were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). Ruthenium (IV) oxide (RuO2, anhydrous; 99.9%) was purchased from Alfa Aesar Co. Inc. (USA). Nafion solution (5 wt %) was purchased from DuPont Co. Ltd. Absolute ethanol, and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 98%) were obtained from Xilong Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Carbon Fiber Paper (CFP) was purchased from Toray Co. Ltd, which was modified hydrothermally with 68% HNO3 at 120 °C for 2 h in sequence to activate the surface of CFP, and then washing with deionized water to neutral and dried at room temperature.

Fe(NO3)3 ·9H2O (0.5 mmol) and fumaric acid (8 mmol) were added to 10 mL of DMF solution and were stirred to form a clear solution. Then the solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined (25 mL) stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 8 h. When it was cooled to room temperature, the precipitates were centrifuged and washed with DMF and ethanol for several times and dried at 30 °C for 12 h.

In a typical synthesis of Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL and Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL, Fe(NO3)3 ·9H2O (0.5 mmol), Ni(NO3)2 ·6H2O/ Co(NO3)2 ·6H2O (0.25 mmol) and fumaric acid (8 mmol) were added to 10 mL of DMF solution in a beaker in sequence. The mixture was subsequently stirred for several minutes to form a clear solution and was transferred to a Teflon-lined (25 mL) stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 8 h. After cooling to room temperature, the products were collected by centrifugation and washed with DMF and ethanol for several times, and dried at 30 °C for 12 h.

Fe(NO3)3 ·9H2O (0.5 mmol), Ni(NO3)2 ·6H2O (0.25 mmol), Co(NO3)2 ·6H2O (0.25 mmol) and fumaric acid (8 mmol) were added to 10 mL of DMF solution and were stirred to form a clear solution. The rest of the procedure was the same as that for the synthesis of d-MOFs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of Fe-based MILs electrodes (Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP, Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL/CFP, Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL/CFP and Fe3-MIL/CFP)
ce:section.ce:para: Take Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP as an example. The mother solution was prepared by dissolved Fe(NO3)3 ·9H2O (0.5 mmol), Ni(NO3)2 ·6H2O (0.25 mmol), Co(NO3)2 ·6H2O(0.25 mmol), and fumaric acid (8 mmol) in 10 mL of DMF by magnetic stirring until a clear solution was formed. Then the obtained clear solution was transferred into the Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, and a piece of modified CFP was placed upright in the Teflon vessel. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 120 °C for 8 h before it was cooled to room temperature. The obtained Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP was washed with ethanol and dried at 30 ºC for 12 h. The Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL/CFP, Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL/CFP and Fe3-MIL/CFP products were obtained by using similar experimental methods and corresponding metal salts, respectively.

For comparison, Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP (Hydrophobic) was also fabricated with a similar procedure to that for the Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP except that hydrophilic carbon fiber paper was replaced by hydrophobic carbon fiber paper.

The structure of samples was analyzed by using a powder X-ray diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.54056 Å, X′ Pert RPO MPD diffractometer, PANalytical B.V) at 293 K. The morphological features were investigated by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Quanta 200 FEG) equipped with a Rontec energy-dispersive X-ray system (EDS). The atomic composition and valence states of the catalyst surface were recorded by employing the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB250) instrument, using a 150 W Al Kα excitation source at 1486.6 eV. Inductively coupled plasma-mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer FLexar-NexION300X spectrometer to further evaluate the relative molar ratio of the metal in the Fe-based MILs.

The electrochemical water oxidation measurements were carried out on an electrochemical analyzer (760E CH Instrument, purchased from Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Co., Ltd.) using a standard three-electrode system in 1.0 M KOH solution.

In this system, Fe-based MILs/CFP (1 cm × 3 cm, submerged surface area 0.5 cm2) was used directly as working electrodes, whereas a platinum electrode and an Ag/AgCl electrode with saturated KCl filling solution were used as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. For comparison, the catalyst suspension was prepared by dispersing 2 mg catalyst powder in 275 μL of a mixed solution containing 125 μL isopropanol, 125 μL deionized water and 25 μL 5 wt % Nafion solution followed by ultrasonication for 30 min. Then 20 μL of the suspension was deposited on carbon fiber paper (1 cm × 3 cm, exposed surface area 0.5 cm2) and then dried at room temperature, yielding a catalyst loading of ~0.30 mg cm−2. The formed electrodes were recorded as Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL and commercial RuO2, respectively. In addition, glassy carbon (GC) electrode (3 mm in diameter, surface = 0.07065 cm2) was also used as the working electrode. The Fe-based MILs catalyst suspension was dropped on the polished GC electrode with a loading of 0.3 mg cm−2 and then dried at room temperature.

The linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) were recorded at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in 1.0 M KOH. All the polarization curves were corrected with 95% iR-compensation. The measured potentials in this work were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) with the Nernst equation: Evs.RHE = E
vs .Ag/AgCl + 0.059 × pH + 0.1989 V. The overpotential (η) was calculated according to the following formula: η (V) = Evs.RHE - 1.23 V. The electrochemically active surface area was evaluated from double-layer capacitance (C dl). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed at different scan rates ranging from 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 to 60 mV s−1 in a potential window (0.8543–0.9543 V vs. RHE) where no Faradaic process occurs. The linear slope of the capacitive current versus scan rate is equivalent to 2C dl. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was obtained in the frequency range from 10 kHz to 0.1 Hz with an AC amplitude of 5 mV at a potential of 1.48 V vs. RHE. The chronopotentiometry to evaluate the stability of the Fe-based MILs/CFP was recorded at a constant current density of 10.0 mA cm−2 without iR compensation.

The density functional calculations were performed in the Vienna ab initio simulation packages (VASP) [25,26], using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) parameterization [27]. We have chosen the projected augmented wave (PAW) potentials to describe the ionic cores and take valence electrons into account [28]. In order to model doping systems, 3 × 3 × 2 supercells were built. The slab models were built by slicing the (011) plane to simulate the surface condition Fe36C108O156 supercell was constructed to represent Fe3-MIL. As for the doped systems, Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156 and Fe30Ni6C108O156 and Fe26Co10C108O156 were built by replacing certain Fe atoms with Ni and Co atoms. Furthermore, the DFT model was described in detail to support the complexity of the multi-metal catalyst model. In order to simulate the complex metal doping system, a large supercell system was built based on Fe3-MIL structure. Considering the tractability of DFT theory, we made a trade-off between tractability and perfectly simulate doping percentage. Thus, the primitive cell was enlarged to 6 times of the original one, and (011) Miller plane was selected to be the plane of interest. The model of Fe26Co10C108O156 was used in this work based on the above established the supercell. Other three doping models were built by replacing the Fe atoms near the surface which had dominated performance on absorption by specific metal atoms like Co and Ni. To be concrete, Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156 was built by replacing two Fe atoms by Ni atoms and eight Fe atoms by Co atoms. Therefore, in this work Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL was modeled by Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156, which is a quite good approximation to the experimental formula. Similarly, Fe26Co10C108O156 was built by replacing ten Fe atoms by Co atoms, i.e. Fe2.16Co0.84-MIL. Fortunately, Fe30Ni6C108O156 could be modeled exactly by replacing six Fe atoms with Ni atoms. Though the models used in the calculation were not exactly the same as those in experiments, the approximation was acceptable and would give a reasonable and correct simulation. A vacuum zone of 15 Å was added along the z-direction to avoid possible interaction between supercells. Thus, only a 1 × 1 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack k-point mesh was used. The convergence criteria were set to 0.05 eV Å−1 for the maximum force. The energy cut-off of the plane wave basis was set as 500 eV. Due to the strong on-site Coulomb repulsion between the d electrons of Fe, Co, and Ni atoms, the DFT + U method with U = 4.0 eV was used for all transition metals according to references [29].

In alkaline medium, the four-electron OER process based on can be described as below:
(1) * + OH- ↔ OH* + e-
(2) OH* + OH- ↔ O* + H2O(l) + e-
(3) O* + OH- ↔ OOH* + e-
(4) OOH* + OH- ↔ * + O2 + H2O(l) + e-
where * represents an active site. The free energies of ORR/OER intermediates are defined as ΔG = ΔE + ΔZPE − TΔS, where ΔE, ΔZPE, T and ΔS represent the reaction energy, zero-point energy, temperature (298.15 K) and the entropy, respectively [30].
(5) △E OH * = E(OH*) – E(*) – [E(H2O) – 1/2 E(H2)]
(6) △E O * = E(O*) – E(*) – [E(H2O) –E(H2)]
(7) △E OOH * = E(OOH*) – E(*) – [2 E(H2O) – 3/2 E(H2)]

The free energy difference for different OER steps (∆G1–4) is calculated as the following:
(8) ΔG 1 = ΔGOH *
(9) ΔG 2 = ΔG O * − ΔG OH *
(10) ΔG 3 = ΔG OOH * − ΔG O *
(11) ΔG 4 = 4.92 – ΔG OOH *

The theoretical overpotential is calculated by the following equation:

Differential charge density was calculated by Ddiff = Dtot - Dsub - Dabs, where Dtot, Dsub and Dabs were charge density of whole system, density of substrate and density of absorbed molecules respectively.

DFT calculations were first employed to investigate the effect of introducing the second or third metal elements into MIL-88A on OER activity. Four kinds of models are constructed for stimulations, corresponding to the single-metallic Fe36C108O156 (Fig. S1a), dual-metallic Fe26Co10C108O156 (Fig. S1b), and Fe30Ni6C108O156 (Fig. S1c), and tri-metallic Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156 (Fig. S1d). For dual-metallic and tri-metallic MILs, the Gibbs free energies (ΔG n, n=1–4) of four elementary reactions during the OER process were calculated on Fe active site. The reaction pathways for OER and the adsorption structures of O*, OH*, and OOH* intermediates for each elementary step are shown in Fig. S2. The rate-determining step (RDS) in the OER process is determined by the maximum change of ΔG [31]. The formation of O* is determined as the RDS of OER for four MIL models. From Fig. 1a, it can be seen that the single-metallic Fe36C108O156 exhibits a high ΔG 2 value of 1.86 eV. For dual-metallic MILs, the ΔG 2 is reduced to 1.62 eV and 1.84 eV for Fe26Co10C108O156 and Fe30Ni6C108O156, respectively, suggesting the reduced energy barrier for the conversion of OH* to O*. When it comes to the tri-metallic Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156, the ΔG 2 (1.53 eV) is smaller than these of Fe36C108O156, Fe26Co10C108O156, and Fe30Ni6C108O156, indicting further enhanced OER activity after incorporation of tri-metallic sites. Further analyses of the charge density difference for OH* adsorbed models (Fig. 1b-e) showed that more charged accumulation at the OH*-substrate interface for Fe26Co10C108O156 and Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156, suggesting the stronger adsorption of OH* [32,33]. The partial density of states (PDOS) of Fe36C108O156, Fe26Co10C108O156, Fe30Ni6C108O156, and Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156 were also calculated for comparison. As shown in Fig. S3, the profile of the d orbital of Fe in Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156 clearly shows a greater overlap with that of the p orbital of OH* intermediate than those of Fe36C108O156, Fe26Co10C108O156, and Fe30Ni6C108O156. Moreover, the overlap region (−4~−2 eV) of Fe26Co10C108O156 is closer to the Fermi level than that (−5~−3 eV) of Fe30Ni6C108O156, implying the better electrochemical performance of dual-metal FeCo-MOF than FeNi-MOF [34,35].
These results suggest that dual-metallic and tri-metallic MILs exhibit better OER activity than single-metallic MIL-88A, verifying the beneficial effect of incorporating multi-metallic sites on OER.

Guided by the theoretical calculations, we synthesized tri-metallic MILs microcrystals to simulate complex DFT models of Fe26Ni2Co8C108O156, which were in-situ grown on hydrophilic carbon fiber paper (CFP) as the electrode for OER. The synthetic procedure is illustrated in Fig. 2. The CFP was directly immersed in the solution containing metal ions (Fe3+, Ni2+and Co2+) and fumaric acid organic ligands. Due to the existence of abundant oxygen functional groups on the hydrophilic CFP surface, metal ions can be evenly adsorbed on the CFP [36–38]. Therefore, the nucleation growth of MILs on the CFP can be achieved through the one-step solvothermal process. The resultant sample is denoted as Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP. Dual-metallic (Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL/CFP and Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL/CFP) and single-metallic (Fe3-MIL/CFP) electrodes were also synthesized by the same method. For comparison, the corresponding tri-metallic, dual-metallic, and single-metallic MILs without the CFP as the substrate were also prepared.

In order to confirm the key role of oxygen-rich functional groups on the surface of CFP in the growth process, hydrophobic CFP was used as the growth substrate for MIL. As displayed in Fig. S4, less Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL on the surface of hydrophobic CFP is loaded, which might be ascribed to the lack of oxygen-containing functional groups on the CFP surface. The results indicate that the oxygen-rich functional groups on hydrophilic CFP can strengthen the interaction between MIL and CFP.

The crystal structure of synthesized samples was examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As revealed in Fig. 3a, all the powder samples share a similar crystal phase to that of the previously reported crystal data (CCDC no. 644016), indicating that incorporating the second or third metal ions into the MIL does not change its crystal structure [39]. Moreover, the characteristic diffraction peaks of MILs are well maintained after in-situ growth on the CFP (Fig. 3b-c). Apart from the carbon peak at 26° arising from the CFP, no other impurity phases can be observed. It should be pointed out that the characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe-based MIL/CFP present a slight shift to the high 2-theta degree compared to the simulated MIL-88A. This could be attributed to the interaction between MILs and carbon fiber substrate [40,41]. For d-MOFs and t-MOFs, the diffraction peaks shift to a low degree, which can be ascribed to the lattice expansion induced by the successful incorporation of foreign metal elements [42–44]. The in-situ growth of MILs on the surface of the conductive CFP is not only conducive to increasing the dispersion of active species but also avoiding the use of the binder. It is expected that the inner resistance of the electrode can be reduced, leading to further improvement of the electrocatalytic performance [45,46].

The morphologies of the as-prepared samples were investigated by the field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM). As presented in Fig. 4a, Fig. S5a, Fig. S6a, and Fig. S7a, the as-prepared MILs microcrystals with different metal ratios present the diamond-like morphology. The average length is ca. 5–6 µm, while the diameter is ca. 4–5 µm (Fig. S8). As depicted in Fig. 4b-c, Fig. S5b-c, Fig. S6b-c, and Fig. S7b, it can be observed that MILs microcrystals are successfully grown on the surface of CFP. The above results suggest that multi-metallic building units and in-situ growth of MILs microcrystals on the substrate could be simultaneously achieved by the one-step solvothermal process. Furthermore, the high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDS) mapping were conducted to analyze the surface element distribution of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL, Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL, Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL, and Fe3-MIL. From Fig. S5d and Fig. S6d, the uniform element distribution presented in Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL and Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL reveals that Ni/Co is homogeneously distributed in MIL-88A. After Co was further introduced into dual-metallic Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL, the elemental mapping images of the resulting Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL displayed the dispersion of Fe, Ni, Co, C, and O elements in the entire architecture (Fig. 4d). To better compare and demonstrate the distribution of surface elements in the control sample, STEM-EDS mapping images of s-MOFs were provided (Fig. S7c). It could be observed that Fe, C, O are homogeneously distributed in Fe3-MIL. Fig. S9 indicated that the EDS of the as-synthesized MILs showed the existence of Fe, Ni, Co, C, O, Au, and Si elements in the samples. The presence of Au and Si originates from the gold spraying and Si foil, respectively. The inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) reveals that the Fe/Ni/Co molar ratio in Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL is 2.1:0.2:0.7. The Fe/Ni and Fe/Co molar ratios are determined to be 2.5:0.5 and 2.2:0.8 in Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL and Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL, respectively, which are consistent with the EDS results (Table S1).

The elemental Fe:Ni:Co ratio of the raw materials was 2:1:1, while that of the product was 2.1:0.2:0.7. Such a gap was due to the solvothermal reaction setup. The inside content consists of precursors and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution before the solvothermal reaction. In contrast, the resultant media in the reaction includes the solid product, residue liquid that contains DMF, unreacted precursors, intermediates and/or side-reaction products. Furthermore, in this chemical reaction, because the identity and concentration of the reactants, together with the experimental conditions, are controlled, the products are surely fixed, i.e., the chemical composition, morphology, and crystalline structure are controllable.

To further investigate the composition and chemical states of as-prepared samples, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted. Fig. S10 reveals the co-existence of Co and Ni elements in the obtained Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL. It should be pointed out that the overlap between Fe 2p and Co LMM peaks and between Co 2p and Fe LMM peaks is normally observed when Al Kα source is used. Therefore, the peak at around 784.8 eV in the survey spectra of Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL can be actually assigned to the Fe LMM peak instead of Co 2p peak. Similarly, the binding energy peak for Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL at around 846 eV is assigned to the Fe LMM Auger transition instead of Ni 2p peak [16,20,21,47,48]. The high-resolution XPS spectrum of C 1 s can be resolved well into three-carbon components at binding energies of about 284.8 eV, 285.8 eV, and 288.2 eV, corresponding to C-C, C-O, and CO, respectively ( Fig. 5a) [49]. The binding energy of 284.8 eV was used as a calibration standard to correct the binding energy of other elements. In the Fe 2p spectrum of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL, Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL, and Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL (Fig. 5b), the curves can be assigned into one pair of peaks and the corresponding satellite peaks. For Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL, the characteristic peaks at 711.2 eV (Fe 2p3/2) and 724.7 eV (Fe 2p1/2) can be assigned to Fe3+ species [50]. Compared to the dual-metallic MILs, the Fe 2p peaks of tri-metallic Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL shift to low binding energy by about 0.3 eV, indicating the altered electronic environment of Fe [42].

Besides, the Ni 2p high-resolution spectrum of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL can be deconvoluted into four peaks, corresponding to the respective Ni 2p3/2 at 855.3 eV and Ni 2p1/2 at 872.6 eV together with their shakeup satellites (Fig. 5c) [51]. Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks for Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL are located at 855.5 eV and 873.1 eV, respectively [52]. In comparison with the Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL, Ni 2p peaks of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL slightly shift to lower binding energy (about 0.2 eV). From Fig. 5d, the two main peaks of Co species at 780.8 eV and 796.5 eV are assigned to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively, indicating the presence of Co2+ in Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL [18]. Compare to the Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL, the peaks of Co 2p of the Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL shift by ca. 0.3 eV to lower binding energy. It is worth noting that all metal elements in the tri-metallic MIL display a negative shift compared with that of the dual-metallic MILs. The above results imply that the introduction of multi-metallic (Ni and Co) elements into Fe3-MIL could modulate the electronic structure and coordination environment of the active center, which can significantly affect the OER catalytic performance of electrocatalysts [53].

Since the OER is a three-phase (gas, liquid and solid) involving process, an appropriate wettability of the electrode enables more active sites to be exposed to the electrolyte, promotes the adsorption of reactants, and facilitates the mass transfer [54]. Therefore, the dynamic contact angle measurement was carried out to probe the interface wettability of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL on different substrates. The smaller contact angle value indicates better surface wettability of materials. As shown in Fig. 6a-b, Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP and Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL powder exhibited a contact angle of 30 degrees and 33 degrees in the 20 ms, respectively. The contact angle of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP decreased dramatically from 30 degrees to 0 after the 60 ms, but the contact angle of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL powder just decreased to 18 degrees. By contrast, the bared carbon fiber paper showed the maximum contact angle value in comparison with the Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL (Fig. 6c), which demonstrated that the high wettability originated from Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0. 7-MIL sample rather than the carbon fiber paper. The results showed that Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP with minimum contact angle value had a better hydrophilic interface, which was conducive to the adsorption of water molecules and fast ionic diffusion [55]. Moreover, the high wettability surface of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP could ensure the accelerated release of oxygen bubbles produced during the OER process and thus deliver improved OER catalytic activity [56,57].

The OER electrocatalytic activities of as-synthesized MILs were investigated by the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurement in 1.0 M KOH in a typical three-electrode system (see the Experimental Section). All LSV test data were corrected by the ohmic potential drop (iR). For comparison, the OER performance of commercial RuO2 catalyst-loaded electrode was also tested. As displayed in Fig. 7a, the optimized Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP electrode possesses the lowest overpotential of 200 mV to achieve a current density 10 mA cm−2 in comparison with Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL/CFP (271 mV), Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL/CFP (235 mV) Fe3-MIL/CFP (288 mV), and commercial RuO2 (344 mV). Besides, attributed to the in-situ growth of MILs, the Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP presents a lower overpotential of 82 mV than that of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL (282 mV) at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. The excellent OER performance could be attributed to the synergistic effect of the incorporation of multi-metallic atoms into Fe3-MIL and in-situ growth of MILs. The performance of the obtained Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP catalyst is also comparable to other outstanding MOFs-based electrocatalysts reported recently (Table S2).

The Tafel plots were assessed as a crucial indicator to reflect the OER kinetics properties of materials. It can be seen from Fig. 7b that Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP deliver a minimum Tafel slope value of 34 mV dec−1, which is lower than that of Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL/CFP (41 mV dec−1), Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL/CFP (38 mV dec−1), Fe3-MIL/CFP (55 mV dec−1), Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL (51 mV dec−1) and commercial RuO2 (74 mV dec−1), implying the most favorable electrochemical kinetics of the tri-metallic Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP electrode. The overpotentials and Tafel slopes of all electrocatalysts were clearly displayed in Fig. 7c for comparison. In addition, the OER performance of the corresponding tri-metallic, dual-metallic, and single-metallic MILs without the CFP as the substrate are also investigated for comparison (Fig. S11). The Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL needs overpotentials of 296 mV to drive a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with a Tafel slope of 40 mV dec−1, which is lower than that of Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL (382 mV, 87 mV dec−1), Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL (332 mV, 55 mV dec−1) and Fe3-MIL (492 mV, 209 mV dec−1). The results further confirm the theoretical calculation conclusion.

The long-term stability is considered a vital parameter for the practical applications of electrocatalysts. Therefore, the chronopotentiometry (V–t) measurements were conducted to assess the durability of as-prepared electrodes. It can be seen from Fig. 7d that there is no significant increase in the potential of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP, Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL/CFP, Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL/CFP, and Fe3-MIL/CFP for 24 h, demonstrating the excellent durability in the catalytic process. The morphology and crystal structure of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP after the chronopotentiometry test was also investigated. Fig. S12 depicted a limited morphological change of Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP after the OER durability test. Moreover, no obvious structure change can be observed in the corresponding XRD pattern.

To further investigate charge transport kinetics, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of electrodes was measured. The Nyquist plots of electrodes and the relevant equivalent circuit model in the form of Rs (Q1, Ro) (Q2, Rct) were displayed in Fig. 8a. Rs devotes the solution resistance, while Ro represents oxide film resistance [58,59]. Q1 and Q2 describe the electron transport of the electrode material/catalyst interface and the catalyst/electrolyte interface, respectively [60]. The charge transfer impedance (Rct) reflects the charge transfer kinetics of the OER catalytic process and further evaluates the OER activity of the electrocatalyst [61]. Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP exhibits a smaller Rct value of 4.64 Ω cm2 than Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL/CFP (8.77 Ω cm2), Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL/CFP (6.22 Ω cm2), Fe3-MIL/CFP (15.79 Ω cm2) and Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL (9.59 Ω cm2), indicating the lowest mass transfer resistance and fastest charge transfer rate for the tri-metallic Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP.

The electrochemical active surface areas (ECSA) of as-prepared MILs/CFP were evaluated by calculating the double-layer capacitance (C dl) according to cyclic voltammograms (CV) at different scan rates (Fig. S13) [62]. As seen from Fig. 8b, Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP has a higher C dl of 6.3 mF cm−2, which is superior to Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL/CFP (0.7 mF cm−2), Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL/CFP (2.5 mF cm−2) and Fe3-MIL/CFP (0.5 mF cm−2), suggesting that more exposed active sites in the tri-metallic MILs arises from the multi-metallic centers.

In this work, our DFT calculations suggest that the incorporation of multiple metal atoms (Co and Ni) into the MIL-88A could lower the activation energy barriers, leading to an improved OER activity compared to the single-metal MIL-88A. Experimentally, Fe3-MIL (s-MOFs), Fe2.2Co0.8-MIL, Fe2.5Ni0.5-MIL (d-MOFs), and Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL (t-MOFs) are successfully in-situ grown on carbon fiber paper via a one-step solvothermal process. The comparison of the electrocatalytic performance of these MOFs electrocatalysts validates the results from DFT calculations. Particularly, the optimized Fe2.1Ni0.2Co0.7-MIL/CFP (t-MOFs) exhibits the superior OER activity with an overpotential of 200 mV at 10 mA cm−2, and a small Tafel slope of 34 mV dec−1 in 1.0 M KOH, which outperforms the commercial RuO2 benchmark and the previous reported MOFs electrocatalysts. The strategy of constructing multi-metal MOFs presents promising potential in the rational design and synthesis of high-performance OER electrocatalysts.
